title: How to Make Strawberry Ice Cream

steps.headline: Rinse, dry, and slice the strawberries.
steps.description: Rinse the strawberries under cool water first, then pat them dry. Chop the stems off, then cut the strawberries into thin slices. The strawberries must be dry. If you let too much water get into your ice cream, you'll get ice crystals in your ice cream.

steps.headline: Combine 2 cups (400 grams) of the strawberries with ⅓ cup (75 grams) of sugar, and 1 teaspoon of lemon juice.
steps.description: Put everything into a bowl, and stir it together with a rubber spatula. Set the remaining ½ cup (100 grams) of strawberries aside for later.

steps.headline: Cover the bowl with plastic wrap, then leave it the fridge for at least 1 hour.
steps.description: This will allow all the flavors to blend together. While this is happening, you can continue preparing the rest of your ice cream. Again, do not add the ½ cup (100 grams) of strawberries into the bowl.

steps.headline: Cook the milk and ¾ cups (170 grams) of sugar in a saucepan over medium-low heat.
steps.description: Stir the milk and sugar with a whisk to help the sugar dissolve. Keep heating it until it is just short of boiling.

steps.headline: Pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the milk mixture into the beaten egg yolks.
steps.description: If you have not already done so, crack open the eggs and separate the yolks from the whites. Discard the whites (or save them for another recipe), and beat the yolks until they turn light and creamy. Slowly pour ½ cup (120 milliliters) of the milk mixture into the eggs while whisking it. This is known as "tempering," and it will prevent the eggs from cooking too quickly and forming clumps.

steps.headline: Pour the egg mixture back into the milk mixture.
steps.description: Be sure to pour the egg mixture slowly, and to stir the milk mixture as you pour.

steps.headline: Cook the milk mixture until it thickens, about 5 minutes.
steps.description: The mixture is ready when it reaches 160°F (72°C), and becomes thick enough to coat the back of a metal spoon.

steps.headline: Pour the milk mixture through a strainer into a bowl, then chill it.
steps.description: The best way to do this would be to fill a sink with ice, and set a bowl into the ice. Place a fine, mesh strainer over the bowl, then pour the milk mixture through it. Discard anything caught in the strainer, and let the milk mixture come to room temperature before chilling it in the fridge for 2 hours. Make sure that the bowl is big enough to hold your heavy whipping cream and strawberries as well.

steps.headline: Purée the chilled strawberries.
steps.description: Just as the milk mixture is almost done chilling, take the strawberries out of the fridge, and pour them into a blender or food processor. Purée them until you get your desired consistency. The longer you purée them for, the smoother your ice cream will be. Try not to leave behind any big chunks, however; that's what your remaining ½ cup (100 grams) of strawberries is for!

steps.headline: Fold the strawberries into the milk mixture, along with the heavy cream.
steps.description: Take the milk mixture out of the fridge, and fold in the puréed strawberries and heavy cream. Keep folding and stirring until the color is even, and you can't see any streaks or swirls. For a more complex flavor, stir in 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Freeze the ice cream.
steps.description: Fill the canister of your ice cream maker two-thirds of the way with the ice cream mixture. Freeze the ice cream according to the manufacturer's instructions; store the remaining ice cream base in the fridge while as freezes. As you finish each batch of ice cream, transfer it to a freezer-safe container, and store it in the freezer. If you don't own an ice cream maker: pour the ice cream into a large, metal loaf pan, and freeze it for 45 minutes. Give it a stir, making sure to break up any ice crystals, then freeze it for another 2 to 4 hours. Stir the ice cream every 30 minutes, and keep it covered with plastic wrap.

steps.headline: Dice the remaining ½ cup (100 grams) of strawberries, then fold them into the ice cream.
steps.description: This will give you that nice, chunky texture that store bought strawberry ice cream has!

steps.headline: Let the ice cream finish freezing, preferably overnight.
steps.description: Once the ice cream comes out of the ice cream maker and you fold in the remaining strawberries, it is technically ready to serve. It will be very soft, however, just like soft-serve ice cream. If you want firmer ice cream, left it "ripen" in the freezer for several hours. It would be best if you let it ripen for 6 to 8 hours, however.

steps.headline: Rinse, dry, and chop up the strawberries.
steps.description: Rinse the strawberries under cool water first, then pat them dry. Chop off the stems, then slice them. Set the strawberries aside while you prepare the ice cream base. You can use frozen strawberries as well, but you will have to let them thaw slightly first.

steps.headline: Purée the strawberries in a blender or food processor.
steps.description: The longer you purée them for, the smoother your ice cream will be. If you want, you can leave some chunks to mimic store-bought strawberry ice cream.

steps.headline: Beat the heavy whipping cream until stiff peaks form.
steps.description: You can do this in an electric, stand mixer, or in a food processor fitted with whisks. You can also use a handheld beater. Keep beating the heavy cream until it becomes thick and fluffy. This will take about 1 minute.

steps.headline: Fold in the condensed milk.
steps.description: Keep beating it until it is just mixed in. This will take about 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Stir in the puréed strawberries using a rubber spatula.
steps.description: Keep stirring until they are mixed in, and no streaks or swirls remain. If you want a pinker ice cream, like the kind you buy in a store, stir in a few drops of red food coloring.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into a large loaf pan, and freeze it for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.description: The larger the loaf pan is, the faster your ice cream will freeze. Keep the ice cream covered with plastic wrap as it freezes. If you want a soft-serve type of ice cream, freeze it for 3 to 4 hours.

steps.headline: Transfer the ice cream into a freezer-safe container, if desired.
steps.description: Once the ice cream is done freezing, you can leave it in the loaf pan, or you can transfer it into something more convenient, such as a plastic, freezer-safe container instead.

steps.headline: Slice and freeze the strawberries and bananas the night before.
steps.description: Peel the banana, cut it into thin slices, and put it into a plastic bag. Chop the stems off of the strawberries, then cut them into slices, and put them into a bag as well. Freeze the fruit overnight.

steps.headline: Purée the strawberries and bananas in a blender or food processor until they turn smooth.
steps.description: From time to time, you may have to pause the blender/food processor, and scrape any unmixed fruit down towards the bottom.

steps.headline: Add the heavy cream and vanilla extract.
steps.description: If you can't find any heavy cream, or if you can't have dairy, here are some other options for you: almond milk, coconut milk, or cow's milk.

steps.headline: Blend the ingredients again until everything is smooth.
steps.description: Every so often, pause the blender/food processor, and use a rubber spatula to scrape any lumps or clumps down towards the bottom.

steps.headline: Scoop the mixture into a freezer-safe container, and freeze it for at least 3 hours.
steps.description: The longer you freeze it for, the firmer it will become. You can also serve it straight out of the blender or food processor as a soft-serve type of ice cream.
